ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How much I hate physics
I learned about electricity, magnetism, and optics.
saying i learned physics would be generous but I learned a general overview of it.
I learned about Electricity and Magnetism and how they relate to each other.
I learned how to think critically and apply physics theory to do mathematical calculations.
I learned a lot of information about E and M.
I learned about many in-depth processes of magnetism, electric fields, etc.
none
Foundational understanding of electricity and magnetism.
I learned about electricity and magnetism.
Knowledge of physics E and M. And problem solving skills
problem solving
None really, I hardly understood anything that was happening in the class.
I learned about electricity and magnetism
2nd semester physics
Basic EM information
I learned the basics of electricity, magnetism, and optics.
Basic electronics and magnetism, solving solving circuits, point charges, charges in magnetic fields
Lots of physics
This course provides a great foundation in concepts in electricity and magnetism, as well as some topics in optics.
A thorough introduction to electricity and magnetism
This class was effectively like AP Physics E and M. We learned about electricity, magnetism, and optics.

I was able to advance my knowledge on the chapters covered during the course and I believe that it was more difficult than the other section, it showed in our testing averages as our section was significantly lower. I'm not sure if I was the only one feeling this way but it felt frustrating at times when it felt like class wasn't as easy to learn the information as my peers in other sections. overall I believe that Gozar is a great person and was very helpful once we were able to get into smaller groups.
I learned about E&M physics

I developed skills about electricity and magnetism

I gained insights into why microscopes, lasers, telescopes and certain electronic devices work the way they do and why it is important to know how circuits work in general
Electrostatics, circuits, magnetism, optics, electromagnetic waves

I learned about Coulomb's law, electric fields, circuits, charges on capacitors, resistance and current, Ohm's law, electric and magnetic forces, magnetic fields generated by moving charges and currents, and voltages generated by changing magnetic fields. I honed my problem-solving skills, similar to in PHYS 180, but the problems in this course were much easier than Steinacker's 180. The content in this course is pretty crazy, it's like magic: you learn how to visualize fields and electricity.
Literally nothing. Everything I learned, I learned from the textbook. Going to class was a waste of time, and I did go to class.
Problem solving skills. Understanding abstract concepts. Critical thinking.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its taught at a pace and level that leaves most students drowning

- i feel it could have been more organized... syllabus wise and in terms of office hours. also, i would not cover that much material in proofs and i would make sure that exams are similar to the homeworks, no harder. for instance, there are so many teaching fellows but none are really helpful... 
- however, it was a nice and well taught course with beautiful slides.
The class feels disorganized because the two sections are taught very differently, and the homework problems don't match the work we do in class.
Homework is less workload with this professor.

the course is hard. I expected it to be hard but I did not expect it to be so hard. While the teachers are doing what they can, no matter how much help I got the material is not clicking. I cannot say I have settled for a C in the course, I am absolutely fighting for my life to earn that C. I want more in class examples of questions like those on the test, sometimes the test questions seemed from another class they were so different.
I feel like the course hits the bases of basic understanding of the phenomena but isn't as challenging as 180 was.

Easy to catch up on due to the nature of the course and the textbook is helpful for learning. Some lectures are more useful than others but you can go to office hours and study hall when confused which is very helpful.
A strength was that the homework was similar to the tests, so you really did get real practice for the tests by doing the psets. A weakness was that there were not many ways to engage during class.
Lectures were much more understandable than 180, I liked this class a lot better. Information was taught well. No corrections were given on exams, making it a bit more difficult compared to 180.
More disorganized than previous 180 segment but appreciated the quizzes and also the use of the textbook as it provided good opportunity for help
Tests did not correlate well with classwork and homework.
not well structured AT ALL, unnecessarily difficult for an intro physics class, concepts were not well explained

This course could be improved with clearer lectures. It was often difficult to see the point of what we were doing, and while I appreciate that the professors wanted us to understand where every equation came from, that came at the expense of learning how to solve problems and practicing things like what we would have on the test.

Strengths: course was dependent on the textbook, which made it easier to re-learn/prepare for content introduced in lectures. Homeworks were also just assigned directly from the textbook, so the workload was insubstantial.

Weaknesses: extremely disorganized, and it felt like a bunch of difficult material was just thrown at us without much structure or cohesiveness. It was a marked contrast from PHYS 180 in the previous semester.
The lecture of this course was difficult to follow and did not work through problems in a way that helped reinforce the concepts or prepared us for the exams.
It was not quite as well run as physics 181 but that makes sense since the professor changed last minute

The main strength of this course was how well the homework problems typically reflected the material learned in class. The weaknesses of this course were how the homework and the material taught in class were not well-reflected in the exams(typically the exams were much more difficult than what was presented in class, the homework required, and the practice problems given out beforehand), how poorly organized the course was generally(my professor was often unable to answer specific questions about upcoming exams in terms of their format, the formula sheet, and material required), and how out of touch the professors seemed to be with the students' levels of understanding of the course material.
workload was very manageable, but more problem solving in class would be helpful
Weakness of class-- the lectures were hard to follow, and we spent so much time deriving the equations we were supposed to use, which was not at all part of the homeworks or the exams.

strengths: I liked how the class followed a book. It was easier to get practice problems to study with. 

weakness: I feel like the exam didn't really capture what we would do in the homework. It also wasn't super clear what material was important to understand. I think this class would benefit from having recorded lectures and to have an entire syllabus listing the sections to study. I felt like this class could also benefit from doing reviews of the material from physics 180
-i hope we could get more practice problems that are similar to the difficulty on the exam

Book reading helped 
professor had a bit of a haphazard teaching style

The course is a little disorganized. I wished curves and grade distributions were more clear. I also dislike how much more difficult the exams are than the problem sets. Lectures were quite confusing at times and the content within lectures weren't always super relevant and helpful.

Lectures felt very unorganized and very rarely left feeling like I understood any of the material. Thankfully the course followed the book closely, so the textbook was a great resource. For the most part, I felt that peer tutors were better resources than TFs when asking questions.
Well rounded

Professor Gozar is a clear, engaging, and thorough teacher whose lectures were well-organized to help us succeed! The weekly problem sets and quizzes were a great way to reinforce the content taught in class.
It could be improved by clearer, more organized powerpoints

The professor was very willing to edit his teaching style so that students could better understand the material being taught. As a course I wish there were a few more examples shown in class that directly related to what we were learning.
There wasn't much taught in lecture that I couldn't learn from the textbook.

Strengths are simple nature of most of the problems but the weaknesses for me were the quality of the lectures. I felt like we went way too fast through most of the material. I also thought it was hard to grasp the simple concepts from lecture in class before going into detailed derivations involving multiple variables.
Lecture content and resources were plentiful, problem sets were very simple compared to the exams

Unlike Steinacker's PHYS 180, where you get lost in the details of the problems, Gaza's 181 left me with a great look at and understanding of the big pictures of electricity and magnetism. So it was good for big-picture topics. The problems for homework probably weren't as hard as they should be, but they got the job done. Teaching was overall terrible in this course, and it seemed like a lot of people weren't really getting anything. I often had to read the textbook. The slides were good at just listing the equations we needed to know, but overall were confusing because the examples in them had too little words/explanation and sometimes had mistakes. Quality of teaching seemed to decline more and more as the semester went on, since Gozar drew out fewer and fewer examples on the board and seemed more and more tired as the semester went on.
My exams also were sometimes graded unclearly and there were mistakes (like points were not allocated as according to the posted grading rubric).
The instructors were so inconsistent and always changing grading policies. The exams were way harder than the homework with clear instruction on how to prepare.

Strengths: There were many fun experiments done in class, and I felt interested in the topics.
Weaknesses: A lot of topics went completely over my head, and the same is true for the rest of the class. I felt like I was lacking a good understanding of what was going on during the last month. It was hard to gain much valuable information from the slides Professor Gozar posted.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No its so bad
I would not recommend this course.
no. Never. please don't take this course if you don't have to.
Yes, it's required. I think it's quite interesting how the math works out so well with interrelated electromagnetic phenomena.

I would only recommend this to a student who has genuine interest in learning physics if it is not a course they are not required to take for their major. Otherwise, I do not think it is worth it if they are not interested.
I would recommend this course if you are really interested in applying math to some real physics scenarios.
If you are interested in E&M I think you would find it fascinating.
Only if you need to take it for your major or pre-med.
absolutely not
I hesitate to recommend it: the material of E&M is fascinating, but this course specifically may not be the best way to deliver that content.
No -- it felt like we were really on our own to understand the material as it was not presented in a way that was really digestible.
Yes. It was a good physics course

I would only recommend this course(specifically with these professors) to a student who already has a strong background in the material covered throughout this class and will not have to rely heavily on the lectures, homework, and exams for understanding.
no, unless it is required for a major
I would recommend this course to people who have to take it. It's not a terrible class and its doable if you take the time out to study.
only if you must
yes, it is a good foundational physics course

I would recommend this course if you like physics and have a good physics background. This class was difficult for me because I never knew the content and the professor tended to assume that we were already proficient to some degree.

Good topics to have a background in regardless which STEM field you plan to enter (not a bad idea to study even in youre not in STEM). Still feels like I largely self taught this material since lectures werent helpful at delivering material
You have to study a lot. Otherwise, go for it.

I would definitely recommend this class to any student thinking about majoring in physics, this course provides a solid foundation in E&M, particularly for those who may not have ever seen this material ever before.
yes
yes, despite it being somewhat disorganized
I would not recommend this course to anyone who isn't an engineering or premed student. It is too much detail for a life-science major and too simple for a physics major.

prof gozar is so sweet and understanding and not condescending (which i really appreciate compared to other physics profs)! but the lectures are not very helpful since the powerpoint slides are posted and everything you need to know is in the textbook. exams are fair and curves are helpful.
Take this course if you have to, or if it's offered by a good professor. Unfortunately the professor in Spring 2022 (for section 2) was not amazing.

Yes, but they would benefit if they have an understanding of electricity and magnetism before entering the class.

I enjoyed learning the material in this class but I have to say that most of it was done on my own simply because I did not understand what I was learning in lecture the first time.

Pretty much everyone takes this as a requirement. I think if Gozar is teaching, you should know that it won't be much work, but if you really want to learn the material you'll need to read the textbook. Steinacker usually teaches this class, and I think her version is a lot harder and much more work. Overall it's very cool material, especially for electrical engineers. Teaching was really bad but textbook is great.
no.
I would recommend it if you're not thinking of majoring in physics. If you are planning on majoring in physics I'd recommend PHYS 201.
